summary: This is an email from ECPAT-USA to an FBI agent, reacting to the conviction of Ghislaine Maxwell. It expresses gratitude for the conviction but emphasizes that justice is incomplete, calling for accountability for the broader network of enablers and powerful men who purchased access to children. It includes statistics on human trafficking convictions and a call to action for government leaders.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The email discusses her recent conviction for her role in facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of young girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as the central figure in a web of crimes against children, with Maxwell and others acting as co-conspirators.

persons.name: Lori L. Cohen
persons.context: Quoted in the email, stating the case is about the powerful men who purchased girls and those who enabled the acts.

persons.name: Sean Watson
persons.context: The email is addressed to this individual at the FBI, indicating communication between an advocacy group and law enforcement.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as a co-conspirator who helped Epstein lure and abuse young girls.
Both are described as perpetrators against the survivors who testified about the abuse they experienced.
Cohen, as CEO of ECPAT-USA, is commenting publicly on Maxwell's conviction and the broader case.

events.title: Conviction of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted in New York for her role in facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Low Federal Human Trafficking Convictions
events.description: Federal courts convicted the lowest number of defendants in human trafficking cases since 2012, with only 163 convictions, a 51% decline from 2019.

events.title: ECPAT-USA Rally for Survivors
events.description: ECPAT-USA Board of Directors and CEO Lori L. Cohen held a rally in support of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell survivors.

locations: Brooklyn, New York 11237 (ECPAT-USA mailing address: 86 Wyckoff Avenue #609)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was convicted in New York in December 2021 for her role in Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking operation.
The email argues the case is not just about Maxwell and Epstein, but also about the 'powerful and influential men who purchased these young girls' and their enablers.
Federal human trafficking convictions dropped 51% from 2019 to 2020, with only 163 defendants convicted in 2020.
The email is sent from an anti-child exploitation advocacy group (ECPAT-USA) to an FBI agent, indicating outreach to law enforcement.
ECPAT-USA calls for elected leaders to send a message that purchasing a child for sex is unacceptable regardless of wealth or power.
